text: Scatters points along the motion trail of a geometry (for particle/fluid emission).
Trail scatter for a line rotating around the origin at 60 degrees/frame.

(Note the rotation arc: although the operator uses only whole-frame geometry
  samples, its spline-interpolation approximates the arc pretty well.)
Point velocities are generated as well, using the similar interpolation.

This node is a general-purpose particle emission helper, to support artifact-less
emission from geometry. It works with all particle types (regular POP, particle fluids, etc.)
It’s also a intended as a direct replacement for flip fluid emitter SOPs.
Since Houdini 13, particle emitters have similar features (as

– partially courtesy of the qLib team ;))
    so using this node is no longer necessary in most cases.

However, this operator is still very useful for FLIP emitters
    (it usually provides

better results than the built-in ones).
    Even for regular particle emitters for a few edge cases – or when more
    sophisticated controls are needed.

This operator scatters points along the motion trail of an animated or deforming geometry.
The motion trail segment length is one frame long by default (when no substepping involved).

The generated trail-scattered points can be used as emission source to get a continuous
particle stream (as opposed to emitting directly from the surface, which will results in
the usual

, so it always produces nicely curved
trails that follow the curvature of the geometry’s movement.
A very important aspect is that
there’s no need to use substepping at all

to get a
continuous emission. (Also, keep in mind that substepping only reduces the problem but
doesn’t eliminate it.)

Velocity vectors can also be generated for the resulting points.
The computation
considers both OBJ and SOP-level transformations

This node also provides support for implementing subframe-accurate particle emission and death
(e.g. for particle simulations that has to be timewarped or retimed into slow-motion).
It can generate subframe-accuracy attributes to be inherited by particles
(
, the latter being the fractional sub-frame birth time).

This node is faster, more controllable, and gives more accurate results
    than the built-in (volume-based) FLIP fluid emitters (in Houdini 12.0.xxx).

To use it with particle fluids, create the fluid emitter as usual (from the shelf),
    then replace the fluid source SOP with this node.

trails, the input geometry is sampled
    at 3 different time samples, which can be expensive. If the geometry input is built from
    lots of SOPs, it’ll be faster if cached before wiring it into the Trail Scatter SOP
    (e.g. with a

This operator doesn’t support geometry with changing topology.
    As an alternative, the

can be used
    to jitter the source geometry along its velocity vectors, before using it as an emitter.

toggle is also not recommended –
    the scattered point locations change so much from frame to frame that the Trail Scatter
    can’t construct a valid trail.
    (It might work for non-deforming geometry, though.)

This value acts as a multiplier on the number of scattered points.
            It can be used to apply gradual changes to particle emission amounts.

Use this value for animating emission (this is explicitly designed for that purpose).

An additional exponent value applied to the multiplier. (The default value of
results of linear changes to the above parameter to appear linear
(Note that for deforming geometry it’s usually better to turn off

Substep (or oversampling) setting of the related DOP (or POP) simulation.
            Make sure the values match (the easiest way of it is to link the DOP or POP
            network’s

Creates the resulting points as a particle system. This is required for particle
            fluids (for the DOP network emitter).
Creates a point group, containing all points.
This can be convenient if used with a

,
                as it requires a source group by default (from Houdini 13).
Parameters for controlling the generated trail.
The direction to extend the trail along (backwards or forwards).

Start and end of the trail, within the current trail time domain.
            (Usually there’s no need to adjust them.)

This parameter acts as a bias on the uniform distribution of trail points.
            (Usually there’s no need to adjust.)
Additional generated attributes on the trail points.

normalized value for each trail point, specifying its relative
            position within the trail.
Since the trail represents a time range (e.g. one frame for substep

This attribute can be used to calculate subframe-accurate particle deaths
            (see

above, but relative to the nearest whole frame.

The value ranges for a substep of
This can be calculated using the expression

The current frames-per-second settings and the current time to pass along to
            the interpolation function.
            Used for generating values for the above attributes.
            Usually there’s no need to touch these.

Controls for the velocity values generated on the points of the trail scatter.
        (It is a weighted sum of multiple velocity sources – make sure the sum of the
        weights (

This is the velocity calculated from the trajectory of the moving
            geometry (individual vector directions are adjusted according to their relative
            position in the trail).
This is the velocity attribute inherited from the source geometry (if exists).

This applies a jitter to the scattered points, along the input velocity vectors (see above).
            This is similar to the method described in
If not set properly, these settings can re-introduce some of the

or similar artifacts. In non-trivial cases some trial-and-error experimenting
            might be needed to get the desired look.
(As a guideline, stick to either Emit or Input velocity and don’t mix them if possible.)
Substeps and the floating point format

is one of the ancient curses of computing in general, whenever an accurate
    representation of real numbers is needed – surprisingly, it can even affect
    simple numeric computations, such as substep counters.
we strongly recommend to always stick to powers-of-2 substep numbers
as they have much less chance to have rounding errors (and hence, missing/doubled cache frames).
but it’s also mentioned here, just to be on the safe side.
jitter points along resulting velocity vectors
make sure emitter velocity has the same magnitude, independent of any substep settings (i think its ok)
velocity scale parameters should work in the negative range as well
(FIXED) animated 'seed' value is not yet supported
(FIXED) forwards/backwards get screwed up at substep 5, 10, (…)

'fix': hackety-hack at world_space/emitter_source_worldspace/slice param
        …should be okay up to about 20 substeps ( blame floating point! :( )
Help card update and other minor UI-related cosmetics.
Added 2nd random seed missing from the UI
Can now create a point group for the resulting points (in accord with the H13 fluid emitter).
Descriptive parm (info displayed in network view)
attributes now define their local variable counterparts.

Added support for creating birth time and birth phase attributes on the generated points
        (allows for subframe-exact particle interpolation).
The first version included in qLib.

title: Trail Scatter qL
summary: Scatters points along the motion trail of a geometry (for particle/fluid emission).
